snippet: Kofi Annan convened a meeting on Saturday of nine global powers who agreed on a plan for political transition in Syria that did not specifically call for President Bashar al-Assad to step down.
abstract: Major world powers fail to reach a consensus on calling for the removal of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria from power, agreeing instead on a plan for a political transition that seems to have little chance of implementation: Kofi Annan convened meeting of nine nations in Geneva, but meeting ends in a now-familiar division, with Russia and China blocking the rest from calling for Assad’s ouster.

byline.original: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ROD NORDLAND
byline.contributor: Nick Cumming-Bruce reported from Geneva, and Rod Nordland from Beirut, Lebanon. Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut; an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria; and Marc Santora from New York.

lead_paragraph: Kofi Annan convened a meeting on Saturday of nine global powers who agreed on a plan for political transition in Syria that did not specifically call for President Bashar al-Assad to step down.

headline.seo: Assad Ouster Blocked in Group’s Crisis Meeting
headline.main: Talks Come Up With Plan for Syria, but Not for Assad’s Exit
headline.print_headline: Powers Agree on Plan for a Syrian Transition, but Not for Removing Assad

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
